### Welcome to **Advanced Research Methods 1**

This is a 10-week course on applied regression modelling for sociologists, first delivered at York St John University (UK). It uses the [`R`](https://www.r-project.org/about.html) programming language and the [`RStudio`](https://www.rstudio.com/) Integrated Development Environment. It takes a [Tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org/) approach to coding and relies heavily on [`R Markdown`](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/index.html) for scripting and reporting.

### Readings

The main textbooks are Gelman, Hill & Vehtari (2020) *Regression and Other Stories* (**ROS**) and Alan Agresti's (2019, 3rd ed.) *Introduction to Categorical Data Analysis* (**ICDA**); if you master the knowledge in these two books, you can call yourself a 21st-century social scientist. 

Sometimes it helps to read about the same topic in a different voice. Ward and Ahlquist's (2018) Maximum likelihood for social science (**MLSS**) is particularly useful for this.

Two further textbooks are useful for specific, more advanced topics such as causality (week 6) and multilevel modelling (week 11): Morgan and Winship (2014) Counterfactuals and Causal Inference: Methods and Principles for Social Research; and Robson and Pevalin (2016) Multilevel Modeling in Plain Language.

Apart from the textbook readings, you should read the selected research articles which demonstrate the application of some of the methods we will learn (and a whole lot that we will not cover!). We will also be using many of the datasets used in those articles and attempt to replicate a few of the published results. Additionally, there are some more technical readings and guides for developing and improving coding skills in the R language. These are also essential to read/complete throughout the module.
